channel.title: R on R. Tyler McLaughlin, PhD
channel.description: Recent content in R on R. Tyler McLaughlin, PhD

item.title: d3-embedding.Rmd
item.description: .node { stroke: #fff; stroke-width: 1.5px; } .link { stroke: #999; stroke-opacity: .6; } D3 is a Javascript library for producing really cool visualizations such as this one and these. According to Wikipedia, D3 offers greater control over the appearance of the final result than other similar libraries. This (probably) means that it requires a bit more Javascript experience than other libraries, but I have to admit Iâ€™m totally new to Javascript.

item.title: d3-embedding.Rmd
item.description: .node { stroke: #fff; stroke-width: 1.5px; } .link { stroke: #999; stroke-opacity: .6; } [D3](https://d3js.org/) is a [Javascript](https://www.javascript.com/) library for producing really cool visualizations such as [this one](http://www.r2d3.us/visual-intro-to-machine-learning-part-1/) and [these](https://github.com/mbostock/d3/wiki/Gallery). According to [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D3.js), D3 offers greater control over the appearance of the final result than other similar libraries. This (probably) means that it requires a bit more Javascript experience than other libraries, but I have to admit I'm totally new to Javascript.

item.title: d3-embedding.Rmd
item.description: .node { stroke: #fff; stroke-width: 1.5px; } .link { stroke: #999; stroke-opacity: .6; } [D3](https://d3js.org/) is a [Javascript](https://www.javascript.com/) library for producing really cool visualizations such as [this one](http://www.r2d3.us/visual-intro-to-machine-learning-part-1/) and [these](https://github.com/mbostock/d3/wiki/Gallery). According to [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D3.js), D3 offers greater control over the appearance of the final result than other similar libraries. This (probably) means that it requires a bit more Javascript experience than other libraries, but I have to admit I'm totally new to Javascript.

item.title: d3-embedding.Rmd
item.description: .node { stroke: #fff; stroke-width: 1.5px; } .link { stroke: #999; stroke-opacity: .6; } [D3](https://d3js.org/) is a [Javascript](https://www.javascript.com/) library for producing really cool visualizations such as [this one](http://www.r2d3.us/visual-intro-to-machine-learning-part-1/) and [these](https://github.com/mbostock/d3/wiki/Gallery). According to [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D3.js), D3 offers greater control over the appearance of the final result than other similar libraries. This (probably) means that it requires a bit more Javascript experience than other libraries, but I have to admit I'm totally new to Javascript.
